title: 梁振英再向英國保守黨人權委員會副主席羅傑斯發公開信

replies.msg:
Dear Mr Rogers,

First, you misspelt my name as “Leung Cheung-ying”. You could have checked. Nonetheless I believe your letter was meant for me.

Secondly, you could have spelt out more clearly for your readers that all sentencing guidelines in Hong Kong are decided by the higher courts of the judiciary, not by the Administration. Any request made by the administration to review sentencing guidelines is for the judiciary to decide.

The rationale for sentencing Edward Leung to six years in jail has been fully set out in the written judgment of the court which you might care to study.

You said “The German Federal Office for Migration and Asylum (BAMF) obviously thought that this type of sentencing ensured that Ray Wong and Alan Li deserved asylum.” We in Hong Kong do not know. The German authorities including the German Consulate General in Hong Kong have refused to tell. If Ray Wong and Alan Li were given asylum on the ground of “disproportionate sentencing”, should we from here on expect Germany to grant asylum to all offenders in the Asian countries that prescribe corporal punishments for misbehaviour in public places, and death sentences for drug trafficking?

Closer to home and still on the question of proportionality, as my first letter pointed out, we have a Mr Kwok Siu-kit who has been detained in Japan since December last year for staging a protest outside the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo. For Hong Kong people not to come to the conclusion that you have a particular bias against Hong Kong, an article from you quizzing the Japanese authorities over their public order laws is expected.

Yours sincerely,
Leung Chun-ying
Former Chief executive
Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
8 June 2019
